title: Bhagavad Gita
author: Veda Vyasa (as part of the Mahabharata)
introduction:
The **Bhagavad Gita** ("Song of the Lord") is a 700-verse Hindu scripture that is part of the epic Mahabharata. It presents a dialogue between Prince Arjuna and his guide and charioteer, Lord Kṛṣṇa.

The setting is the battlefield of Kurukṣetra, just before the start of the great war between the Pāṇḍavas and the Kauravas. Overwhelmed by moral dilemma and despair at the thought of fighting his own kinsmen, teachers, and friends, Arjuna refuses to fight.

Kṛṣṇa then imparts transcendental knowledge, covering the principles of duty (Dharma), the nature of the soul (Ātman), devotion (Bhakti), action (Karma Yoga), and knowledge (Jñāna Yoga). The 18 chapters of the Gita are often referred to as 18 Yogas (disciplines or paths to spiritual realization). The essence of the Gita is to encourage selfless action and devotion, regardless of worldly outcomes.

chapters.name: Arjuna Viṣāda Yoga
chapters.summary: The Yoga of Arjuna's Despair. Arjuna assesses the armies, identifies his kinsmen as enemies, and is overcome by sorrow (viṣāda) and moral conflict, resolving not to fight.

verses.original:
धर्मक्षेत्रे कुरुक्षेत्रे समवेता युयुत्सवः ।
मामकाः पाण्डवाश्चैव किमकुर्वत सञ्जय ॥
verses.transliteration:
dharmakṣetre kurukṣetre samavetā yuyutsavaḥ |
māmakāḥ pāṇḍavāścaiva kimakurvata sañjaya ||

translations.english: Dhritarashtra said: O Sañjaya, assembled in the sacred field (dharmakṣetra), the field of the Kurus (kurukṣetre), eager for battle, what did my sons and the sons of Pāṇḍu do?

verses.original:
दृष्ट्वा तु पाण्डवानीकं व्यूढं दुर्योधनस्तदा ।
आचार्यमुपसङ्गम्य राजा वचनमब्रवीत् ॥
verses.transliteration:
dṛṣṭvā tu pāṇḍavānīkaṁ vyūḍhaṁ duryodhanastadā |
ācāryamupasaṅgamya rājā vacanamabravīt ||

translations.english: Sanjaya said: Having seen the army of the Pāṇḍavas arrayed for battle, King Duryodhana approached his teacher (Droṇa) and spoke these words.

verses.original:
पश्यैतां पाण्डुपुत्राणामाचार्य महतीं चमूम् ।
व्यूढां द्रुपदपुत्रेण तव शिष्येण धीमता ॥
verses.transliteration:
paśyaitāṁ pāṇḍuputrāṇām-ācārya mahatīṁ camūm |
vyūḍhāṁ drupada-putreṇa tava śiṣyeṇa dhīmatā ||

translations.english: O my teacher, behold this great army of the sons of Pāṇḍu, skillfully arranged for battle by the son of Drupada, your intelligent disciple (Dhṛṣṭadyumna).

verses.original:
अत्र शूरा महेष्वासा भीमार्जुनसमा युधि ।
युयुधानो विराटश्च द्रुपदश्च महारथः ॥
verses.transliteration:
atra śūrā mahēṣvāsā bhīmārjunā-samā yudhi |
yuyudhānō virāṭaśca drupadaśca mahārathaḥ ||

translations.english: Here are heroes, great archers, equal in battle to Bhīma and Arjuna—Yuyudhāna, Virāṭa, and Drupada, the great chariot warrior (Mahāratha).

verses.original:
धृष्टकेतुश्चेकितानः काशिराजश्च वीर्यवान् ।
पुरुजित्कुन्तिभोजश्च शैब्यश्च नरपुङ्गवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
dhṛṣṭakētuś-cēkitānaḥ kāśirājaśca vīryavān |
purujit-kuntibhōjaśca śaibyaśca narapuṅgavaḥ ||

translations.english: Dhṛṣṭaketu, Cekitāna, the valiant king of Kāśi, Purujit, Kuntibhōja, and Śaibya, the best of men.

verses.original:
युधामन्युश्च विक्रान्त उत्तमौजाश्च वीर्यवान् ।
सौभद्रो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्व एव महारथाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yudhāmanyuśca vikrānta uttamaujāśca vīryavān |
saubhadrō draupadēyāśca sarva ēva mahārathāḥ ||

translations.english: The mighty Yudhamanyu and the valiant Uttamaujā; the son of Subhadrā (Abhimanyu), and the sons of Draupadī—all of them are great chariot warriors.

verses.original:
अस्माकं तु विशिष्टा ये तान्निबोध द्विजोत्तम ।
नायका मम सैन्यस्य संज्ञार्थं तान्ब्रवीमि ते ॥
verses.transliteration:
asmākaṁ tu viśiṣṭā yē tānnibōdha dvijōttama |
nāyakā mama sainyasya saṁjñārthaṁ tānbravīmi tē ||

translations.english: O best of the twice-born (Droṇa), know also the distinguished ones on our side, the leaders of my army; I name them for your information.

verses.original:
भवान्भीष्मश्च कर्णश्च कृपश्च समितिञ्जयः ।
अश्वत्थामा विकर्णश्च सौमदत्तिस्तथैव च ॥
verses.transliteration:
bhavānbhīṣmaśca karṇaśca kṛpaśca samitiñjayaḥ |
aśvatthāmā vikarṇaśca saumadattistathaiva ca ||

translations.english: Yourself (Droṇa), Bhīṣma, Karṇa, and Kṛpa, who is ever-victorious in battle; Aśvatthāmā, Vikarṇa, and also the son of Somadatta (Bhooriśravā).

verses.original:
अन्ये च बहवः शूरा मदर्थे त्यक्तजीविताः ।
नानाशस्त्रप्रहरणाः सर्वे युद्धविशारदाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
anyē ca bahavaḥ śūrā madarthē tyaktajīvitāḥ |
nānāśastra-praharaṇāḥ sarvē yuddhaviśāradāḥ ||

translations.english: And many other heroes, who are ready to lay down their lives for my sake, are here; they are all expert in various weapons and skilled in warfare.

verses.original:
अपर्याप्तं तदस्माकं बलं भीष्माभिरक्षितम् ।
पर्याप्तं त्विदमेतेषां बलं भीमाभिरक्षितम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
aparyāptaṁ tadasmākaṁ balaṁ bhīṣmābhirakṣitam |
paryāptaṁ tvidam-ētēṣāṁ balaṁ bhīmābhirakṣitam ||

translations.english: Our strength, protected by Bhīṣma, is immeasurable; while their strength, protected by Bhīma, is quite measurable.

verses.original:
अयनेषु च सर्वेषु यथाभागमवस्थिताः ।
भीष्ममेवाभिरक्षन्तु भवन्तः सर्व एव हि ॥
verses.transliteration:
ayanēṣu ca sarvēṣu yathābhāgamavasthitāḥ |
bhīṣmam-ēvābhirakṣantu bhavantaḥ sarva ēva hi ||

translations.english: Therefore, taking your proper positions at the strategic points of the battle array, you should all support and protect Bhīṣma completely.

verses.original:
तस्य सञ्जनयन्हर्षं कुरुवृद्धः पितामहः ।
सिंहनादं विनद्योच्चैः शङ्खं दध्मौ प्रतापवान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
tasya sañjanayan-harṣaṁ kuruvṛddhaḥ pitāmahaḥ |
siṁhanādaṁ vinadyōccaiḥ śaṅkhaṁ dadhmau pratāpavān ||

translations.english: Then, the powerful elder of the Kuru dynasty, the grandsire Bhīṣma, roaring like a lion, blew his conch shell (śaṅkha), bringing joy to Duryodhana.

verses.original:
ततः शङ्खाश्च भेर्यश्च पणवानकगोमुखाः ।
सहसैवाभ्यहन्यन्त स शब्दस्तुमुलोऽभवत् ॥
verses.transliteration:
tataḥ śaṅkhāśca bhēryaśca paṇavānakagōmukhāḥ |
sahasaivābhyahanyanta sa śabdastumulō-’bhavat ||

translations.english: Immediately after, conch shells, kettledrums (bhēryas), small drums (paṇavānakas), and horns (gōmukhāḥ) were sounded suddenly, and the tumultuous noise was deafening.

verses.original:
ततः श्वेतैर्हयैर्युक्ते महति स्यन्दने स्थितौ ।
माधवः पाण्डवश्चैव दिव्यौ शङ्खौ प्रदध्मतुः ॥
verses.transliteration:
tataḥ śvētair-hayair-yukte mahati syandanē sthitau |
mādhavaḥ pāṇḍavaścaiva divyau śaṅkhau pradadhmatuḥ ||

translations.english: Then, stationed in a magnificent chariot drawn by white horses, Kṛṣṇa (Mādhava) and Arjuna (Pāṇḍava) sounded their divine conch shells.

verses.original:
पाञ्चजन्यं हृषीकेशो देवदत्तं धनञ्जयः ।
पौण्ड्रं दध्मौ महाशङ्खं भीमकर्मा वृकोदरः ॥
verses.transliteration:
pāñcajanyaṁ hṛṣīkēśō dēvadattaṁ dhanañjayaḥ |
pauṇḍraṁ dadhmau mahāśaṅkhaṁ bhīmakarmā vṛkōdaraḥ ||

translations.english: Kṛṣṇa (Hṛṣīkēśa) blew his conch Pāñcajanya, Arjuna (Dhanañjaya) blew Devadatta, and Bhīma, the doer of terrible deeds (Vṛkōdara), blew his great conch Pauṇḍra.

verses.original:
अनन्तविजयं राजा कुन्तीपुत्रो युधिष्ठिरः ।
नकुलः सहदेवश्च सुघोषमणिपुष्पकौ ॥
verses.transliteration:
anantavijayaṁ rājā kuntīputrō yudhiṣṭhiraḥ |
nakulaḥ sahadēvaśca sughōṣamaṇipuṣpakau ||

translations.english: King Yudhiṣṭhira, the son of Kuntī, blew Anantavijayam, and Nakula and Sahadeva blew Sughōṣa and Maṇipuṣpaka, respectively.

verses.original:
काश्यश्च परमेष्वासः शिखण्डी च महारथः ।
धृष्टद्युम्नो विराटश्च सात्यकिश्चापराजितः ॥
verses.transliteration:
kāśyaśca paramēṣvāsaḥ śikhaṇḍī ca mahārathaḥ |
dhṛṣṭadyumnō virāṭaśca sātyakiścāparājitaḥ ||

translations.english: And the supreme archer, the King of Kāśi, the great chariot warrior Śikhaṇḍī, Dhṛṣṭadyumna, Virāṭa, and the unconquerable Sātyaki.

verses.original:
द्रुपदो द्रौपदेयाश्च सर्वशः पृथिवीपते ।
सौभद्रश्च महाबाहुः शङ्खान्दध्मुः पृथक्पृथक् ॥
verses.transliteration:
drupadō draupadēyāśca sarvaśaḥ pṛthivīpate |
saubhadraśca mahābāhuḥ śaṅkhāndadhmuḥ pṛthakpṛthak ||

translations.english: Drupada, the sons of Draupadī, and the mighty-armed son of Subhadrā (Abhimanyu)—all these, O King (Dhṛtarāṣṭra), blew their conch shells separately.

verses.original:
स घोषो धार्तराष्ट्राणां हृदयानि व्यदारयत् ।
नभश्च पृथिवीं चैव तुमुलो व्यनुनादयन् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sa ghōṣō dhārtarāṣṭrāṇāṁ hṛdayāni vyadārayat |
nabhaśca pṛthivīṁ caiva tumulō vyanunādayan ||

translations.english: That tremendous sound, reverberating throughout the sky and the earth, pierced the hearts of Dhṛtarāṣṭra’s sons (Kauravas).

verses.original:
अथ व्यवस्थितान्दृष्ट्वा धार्तराष्ट्रान् कपिध्वजः ।
प्रवृत्ते शस्त्रसम्पाते धनुरुद्यम्य पाण्डवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
atha vyavasthitāndṛṣṭvā dhārtarāṣṭrān kapidhvajaḥ |
pravṛtte śastra-sampātē dhanur-udyamya pāṇḍavaḥ ||

translations.english: Then, seeing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra standing arrayed, and the discharge of weapons about to begin, Arjuna (Kapidhvaja), the son of Pāṇḍu, raised his bow.

verses.original:
हृषीकेशं तदा वाक्यमिदमाह महीपते ।
अर्जुन उवाच ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये रथं स्थापय मेऽच्युत ॥
verses.transliteration:
hṛṣīkēśaṁ tadā vākyam-idam-āha mahīpate |
arjuna uvāca |
senayōr-ubhayōr-madhye rathaṁ sthāpaya mē-’cyuta ||

translations.english: O King, Arjuna then spoke this word to Kṛṣṇa (Hṛṣīkēśa): Arjuna said: O Infallible One (Acyuta), please place my chariot between the two armies.

verses.original:
यावदेतान्निरीक्षेऽहं योद्धुकामानवस्थितान् ।
कैर्मया सह योद्धव्यमस्मिन् रणसमुद्यमे ॥
verses.transliteration:
yāvad-ētān-nirīkṣē-’haṁ yōddhukāmān-avasthitān |
kair-mayā saha yōddhavyam-asmin raṇa-samudyame ||

translations.english: So that I may look at these who are standing here eager to fight, and know with whom I must fight in this great endeavor of battle.

verses.original:
योत्स्यमानान् अवेक्षेऽहं य एतेऽत्र समागताः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रस्य दुर्बुद्धेर् युद्धे प्रियचिकीर्षवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yōtsyamānān avēkṣē-’haṁ ya ēte-’tra samāgatāḥ |
dhārtarāṣṭrasya durbuddhēr yuddhē priya-cikīrṣavaḥ ||

translations.english: I wish to see those who are assembled here, prepared for battle, desiring to please the evil-minded son of Dhṛtarāṣṭra (Duryodhana).

verses.original:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
एवमुक्तो हृषीकेशो गुडाकेशेन भारत ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये स्थापयित्वा रथोत्तमम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca |
ēvam-uktō hṛṣīkēśō guḍākēśēna bhārata |
senayōr-ubhayōr-madhye sthāpayitvā rathōttamam ||

translations.english: Sanjaya said: O descendant of Bharata (Dhṛtarāṣṭra), thus requested by Arjuna (Guḍākēśa), Kṛṣṇa (Hṛṣīkēśa) placed the best of chariots between the two armies.

verses.original:
भीष्मद्रोणप्रमुखतः सर्वेषां च महीक्षिताम् ।
उवाच पार्थ पश्यैतान् समवेतान् कुरूनिति ॥
verses.transliteration:
bhīṣmadrōṇa-pramukhataḥ sarvēṣāṁ ca mahīkṣitām |
uvāca pārtha paśyaitān samavētān kurūn-iti ||

translations.english: In front of Bhīṣma and Droṇa and all the rulers of the world, He said: "O son of Pṛthā (Arjuna), behold these Kurus assembled here."

verses.original:
तत्रापश्यत्स्थितान् पार्थः पितॄनथ पितामहान् ।
आचार्यान्मातुलान्भ्रातॄन्पुत्रान्पौत्रान्सखींस्तथा ॥
verses.transliteration:
tatrāpaśyat-sthitān pārthaḥ pitṝn-atha pitāmahān |
ācāryān-mātulān-bhrātṝn-putrān-pautrān-sakhīṁs-tathā ||

translations.english: There, Arjuna (Pārtha) saw stationed fathers, grandfathers, teachers, maternal uncles, brothers, sons, grandsons, and also friends.

verses.original:
श्वशुरान्सुहृदश्चैव सेनयोरुभयोरपि ।
तान्समीक्ष्य स कौन्तेयः सर्वान्बन्धूनवस्थितान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
śvaśurān-suhṛdaś-caiva senayōr-ubhayōr-api |
tān-samīkṣya sa kauntēyaḥ sarvān-bandhūn-avasthitān ||

translations.english: Fathers-in-law and well-wishers also, in both armies. Seeing all these relatives (bandhūn) present, Arjuna (Kauntēya) was overwhelmed with compassion.

verses.original:
कृपया परयाविष्टो विषीदन्निदमब्रवीत् ।
अर्जुन उवाच ।
दृष्ट्वेमं स्वजनं कृष्ण युयुत्सुं समुपस्थितम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
kṛpayā parayāviṣṭō viṣīdannidam-abravīt |
arjuna uvāca |
dṛṣṭvēmaṁ svajanaṁ kṛṣṇa yuyutsuṁ samupasthitam ||

translations.english: Overwhelmed by deep compassion, and grieving, he spoke thus: Arjuna said: Seeing these kinsmen (svajanaṁ), O Kṛṣṇa, assembled and eager to fight...

verses.original:
सीदन्ति मम गात्राणि मुखं च परिशुष्यति ।
वेपथुश्च शरीरे मे रोमहर्षश्च जायते ॥
verses.transliteration:
sīdanti mama gātrāṇi mukhaṁ ca pariśuṣyati |
vēpathuśca śarīrē mē rōmaharṣaśca jāyate ||

translations.english: My limbs fail me, and my mouth is parched; trembling is in my body, and my hair stands on end.

verses.original:
गाण्डीवं स्रंसते हस्तात्त्वक्चैव परिदह्यते ।
न च शक्नोम्यवस्थातुं भ्रमतीव च मे मनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
gāṇḍīvaṁ sraṁsate hastāt-tvak-caiva paridahyate |
na ca śaknōmy-avasthātuṁ bhramatīva ca mē manaḥ ||

translations.english: My bow Gāṇḍīva slips from my hand, and my skin burns all over; I am unable to stand steady, and my mind seems to reel.

verses.original:
निमित्तानि च पश्यामि विपरीतानि केशव ।
न च श्रेयोऽनुपश्यामि हत्वा स्वजनमाहवे ॥
verses.transliteration:
nimittāni ca paśyāmi viparītāni kēśava |
na ca śrēyō-’nupaśyāmi hatvā svajanam-āhavē ||

translations.english: And I see inauspicious omens, O Keśava. I foresee no good in killing my own kinsmen in battle.

verses.original:
न काङ्क्षे विजयं कृष्ण न च राज्यं सुखानि च ।
किं नो राज्येन गोविन्द किं भोगैर्जीवितेन वा ॥
verses.transliteration:
na kāṅkṣē vijayaṁ kṛṣṇa na ca rājyaṁ sukhāni ca |
kiṁ nō rājyēna gōvinda kiṁ bhōgair-jīvitēna vā ||

translations.english: I desire neither victory, O Kṛṣṇa, nor kingdom, nor happiness. Of what use is a kingdom to us, O Govinda, or enjoyment, or even life itself?

verses.original:
येषामर्थे काङ्क्षितं नो राज्यं भोगाः सुखानि च ।
त इमेऽवस्थिता युद्धे प्राणान्स्त्यक्त्वा धनानि च ॥
verses.transliteration:
yēṣām-arthe kāṅkṣitaṁ nō rājyaṁ bhōgāḥ sukhāni ca |
ta ime-’vasthitā yuddhē prāṇāns-tyaktvā dhanāni ca ||

translations.english: For whose sake we desire kingdom, enjoyments, and happiness—those very teachers, fathers, sons, grandfathers, maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives are standing here in battle, having renounced life and wealth.

verses.original:
आचार्याः पितरः पुत्रास्तथैव च पितामहाः ।
मातुलाः श्वशुराः पौत्राः श्यालाः सम्बन्धिनस्तथा ॥
verses.transliteration:
ācāryāḥ pitaraḥ putrās-tathaiva ca pitāmahāḥ |
mātulāḥ śvaśurāḥ pautrāḥ śyālāḥ sambandhinastathā ||

translations.english: Teachers, fathers, sons, and grandfathers; maternal uncles, fathers-in-law, grandsons, brothers-in-law, and other relatives.

verses.original:
एतान्न हन्तुमिच्छामि घ्नतोऽपि मधुसूदन ।
अपि त्रैलोक्यराज्यस्य हेतोः किं नु महीकृते ॥
verses.transliteration:
ētān na hantum-icchāmi ghnato-’pi madhusūdana |
api trailōkya-rājyasya hētōḥ kiṁ nu mahīkṛte ||

translations.english: These I do not wish to kill, even if they kill me, O Madhusūdana (Kṛṣṇa), even for the sake of the sovereignty of the three worlds. How much less for the sake of the earth?

verses.original:
निहत्य धार्तराष्ट्रान्नः का प्रीतिः स्याज्जनार्दन ।
पापमेवाश्रयेदस्मान् हत्वैतानाततायिनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
nihatya dhārtarāṣṭrān-naḥ kā prītiḥ syāj-janārdana |
pāpam-ēvāśrayēd-asmān hatvāi-tān-ātatāyinaḥ ||

translations.english: What pleasure shall be ours, O Janārdana (Kṛṣṇa), by killing the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra? Sin alone will accrue to us by slaying these aggressors.

verses.original:
तस्मान्नार्हा वयं हन्तुं धार्तराष्ट्रान् स्वबान्धवान् ।
स्वजनं हि कथं हत्वा सुखिनः स्याम माधव ॥
verses.transliteration:
tasmān-nārhā vayaṁ hantuṁ dhārtarāṣṭrān svabāndhavān |
svajanaṁ hi kathaṁ hatvā sukhinaḥ syāma mādhava ||

translations.english: Therefore, we should not kill the sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, our kinsmen. How can we be happy by killing our own relatives, O Mādhava (Kṛṣṇa)?

verses.original:
यद्यप्येते न पश्यन्ति लोभोपहतचेतसः ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं मित्रद्रोहे च पातकम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadyapy-ēte na paśyanti lōbhōpahata-cētasaḥ |
kulakṣaya-kṛtaṁ dōṣaṁ mitra-drōhē ca pātakam ||

translations.english: Although these people, whose minds are overcome by greed, see no fault in destroying the family or committing treason against friends...

verses.original:
कथं न ज्ञेयमस्माभिः पापादस्मान्निवर्तितुम् ।
कुलक्षयकृतं दोषं प्रपश्यद्भिर्जनार्दन ॥
verses.transliteration:
kathaṁ na jñēyam-asmābhiḥ pāpād-asmān-nivartitum |
kulakṣaya-kṛtaṁ dōṣaṁ prapaśyadbhir-janārdana ||

translations.english: ...why should not we, O Janārdana, who clearly see the evil (dōṣaṁ) caused by the destruction of the family, know how to turn away from this sin?

verses.original:
कुलक्षये प्रणश्यन्ति कुलधर्माः सनातनाः ।
धर्मे नष्टे कुलं कृत्स्नमधर्मोऽभिभवत्युत ॥
verses.transliteration:
kulakṣaye praṇaśyanti kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ |
dharmē naṣṭe kulaṁ kṛtsnam-adharmo-’bhibhavaty-uta ||

translations.english: In the destruction of the family, the eternal family traditions (kuladharmāḥ sanātanāḥ) perish; with the destruction of virtue (dharma), vice (adharma) completely overtakes the entire family.

verses.original:
अधर्माभिभवात्कृष्ण प्रदुष्यन्ति कुलस्त्रियः ।
स्त्रीषु दुष्टासु वार्ष्णेय जायते वर्णसङ्करः ॥
verses.transliteration:
adharmābhibhavāt-kṛṣṇa praduṣyanti kula-striyaḥ |
strīṣu duṣṭāsu vārṣṇēya jāyate varṇasaṅkaraḥ ||

translations.english: O Kṛṣṇa, when vice prevails, the women of the family become corrupted; and when women are corrupted, O Vārṣṇēya, confusion of castes (varṇasaṅkaraḥ) arises.

verses.original:
सङ्करो नरकायैव कुलघ्नानां कुलस्य च ।
पतन्ति पितरो ह्येषां लुप्तपिण्डोदकक्रियाः ॥
verses.transliteration:
saṅkarō narakāyāiva kulaghnānāṁ kulasya ca |
patanti pitarō hy-ēṣāṁ lupta-piṇḍōdaka-kriyāḥ ||

translations.english: This confusion leads the family-destroyers and the family to hell; and their ancestors fall down, deprived of the offerings of rice-balls (piṇḍa) and water.

verses.original:
दोषैरेतैः कुलघ्नानां वर्णसङ्करकारकैः ।
उत्साद्यन्ते जातिधर्माः कुलधर्माश्च शाश्वताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
dōṣair-ētaiḥ kulaghnānāṁ varṇasaṅkara-kārakaiḥ |
utsādyante jātidharmāḥ kuladharmāśca śāśvatāḥ ||

translations.english: By these evil deeds of the family-destroyers, which create confusion of castes, the eternal community duties (jātidharmāḥ) and family duties (kuladharmāḥ) are destroyed.

verses.original:
उत्सन्नकुलधर्माणां मनुष्याणां जनार्दन ।
नरके नियतं वासो भवतीत्यनुशुश्रुम ॥
verses.transliteration:
utsanna-kuladharmāṇāṁ manuṣyāṇāṁ janārdana |
narake niyataṁ vāsō bhavatīty-anuśuśruma ||

translations.english: O Janārdana, we have heard that men whose family duties are destroyed must dwell in hell forever.

verses.original:
अहो बत महत्पापं कर्तुं व्यवसिता वयम् ।
यद्राज्यसुखलोभेन हन्तुं स्वजनमुद्यताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
ahō bata mahat-pāpaṁ kartuṁ vyavasitā vayam |
yad-rājya-sukha-lōbhena hantuṁ svajanam-udyatāḥ ||

translations.english: Alas! We are intent on committing a great sin, in that we are prepared to kill our own kinsmen out of greed for the pleasures of a kingdom.

verses.original:
यदि मामप्रतीकारमशस्त्रं शस्त्रपाणयः ।
धार्तराष्ट्रा रणे हन्युस्तन्मे क्षेमतरं भवेत् ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadi mām-apratīkāram-aśastraṁ śastra-pāṇayaḥ |
dhārtarāṣṭrā raṇe hanyus-tan-me kṣēmataraṁ bhavēt ||

translations.english: It would be better for me if the armed sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra were to kill me in battle, unresisting and unarmed (apratīkāram-aśastram).

verses.original:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
एवमुक्त्वाऽर्जुनः सङ्ख्ये रथोपस्थ उपाविशत् ।
विसृज्य सशरं चापं शोकसंविग्नमानसः ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca |
ēvam-uktvā-’rjunaḥ saṅkhyē rathōpastha upāviśat |
visṛjya saśaraṁ cāpaṁ śōka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ ||

translations.english: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus on the battlefield, Arjuna sank down onto the seat of the chariot, casting aside his bow and arrows, his mind overcome with grief (śōka-saṁvigna-mānasaḥ).

chapters.name: Sāṅkhya Yoga
chapters.summary: The Yoga of Knowledge (Sankhya). Kṛṣṇa begins His instruction, focusing on the immortality of the soul (Ātman), the necessity of performing one's duty (Dharma), and the path of selfless action (Karma Yoga).

verses.original:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
तं तथा कृपयाविष्टमश्रुपूर्णाकुलेक्षणम् ।
विषीदन्तमिदं वाक्यमुवाच मधुसूदनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca |
taṁ tathā kṛpayāviṣṭam-aśru-pūrṇ-ākul-ēkṣaṇam |
viṣīdantam-idaṁ vākyam-uvāca madhusūdanaḥ ||

translations.english: Sanjaya said: To him (Arjuna), who was thus overwhelmed by compassion, whose eyes were full of tears and distressed, and who was despairing, Kṛṣṇa (Madhusūdana) spoke these words.

verses.original:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
कुतस्त्वा कश्मलमिदं विषमे समुपस्थितम् ।
अनार्यजुष्टमस्वर्ग्यमकीर्तिकरमर्जुन ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān-uvāca |
kutas-tvā kaśmalam-idaṁ viṣamē samupasthitam |
anārya-juṣṭam-asvargyam-akīrti-karam-arjuna ||

translations.english: The Supreme Lord said: O Arjuna, how has this delusion (kaśmalam), unworthy of an Ārya (noble person), arisen in you at this critical time? It neither leads to heaven nor to fame.

verses.original:
क्लैब्यं मा स्म गमः पार्थ नैतत्त्वय्युपपद्यते ।
क्षुद्रं हृदयदौर्बल्यं त्यक्त्वोत्तिष्ठ परन्तप ॥
verses.transliteration:
klaibyaṁ mā sma gamaḥ pārtha naitat-tvayy-upapadyate |
kṣudraṁ hṛdaya-daurbalyaṁ tyaktvōttiṣṭha parantapa ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā (Arjuna), do not yield to impotence; it is not worthy of you. Abandon this petty faint-heartedness, O scorcher of foes, and arise!

verses.original:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
कथं भीष्ममहं सङ्ख्ये द्रोणं च मधुसूदन ।
इषुभिः प्रतियोत्स्यामि पूजार्हावरिसूदन ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca |
kathaṁ bhīṣmam-ahaṁ saṅkhyē drōṇaṁ ca madhusūdana |
iṣubhiḥ pratiyōtsyāmi pūjārhāv-arisūdana ||

translations.english: Arjuna said: O Madhusūdana, how can I fight with arrows in battle against Bhīṣma and Droṇa, who are worthy of worship, O destroyer of enemies?

verses.original:
गुरूनहत्वा हि महानुभावान् श्रेयो भोक्तुं भैक्ष्यमपीह लोके ।
हत्वार्थकामांस्तु गुरूनिहैव भुञ्जीय भोगान् रुधिरप्रदिग्धान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
gurūn-ahatvā hi mahānubhāvān śrēyō bhōktuṁ bhaikṣyam-apīha lōkē |
hatvārtha-kāmāṁs-tu gurūn-ihaiva bhuñjīya bhōgān rudhira-pradigdhān ||

translations.english: It is better to live on alms in this world without killing these great-souled gurus. But if I kill the gurus who are desirous of wealth (artha-kāmān), I shall only enjoy blood-stained pleasures here.

verses.original:
न चैतद्विद्मः कतरन्नो गरीयो यद्वा जयेम यदि वा नो जयेयुः ।
यानेव हत्वा न जिजीविषामः तेऽवस्थिताः प्रमुखे धार्तराष्ट्राः ॥
verses.transliteration:
na caitad-vidmaḥ katarannō garīyō yad-vā jayēma yadi vā nō jayēyuḥ |
yān-ēva hatvā na jijīviṣāmaḥ tē-’vasthitāḥ pramukhe dhārtarāṣṭrāḥ ||

translations.english: Nor do we know which is better: whether we should conquer them, or they should conquer us. The very sons of Dhṛtarāṣṭra, after killing whom we would not wish to live, are standing before us.

verses.original:
कार्पण्यदोषोपहतस्वभावः पृच्छामि त्वां धर्मसम्मूढचेताः ।
यच्छ्रेयः स्यान्निश्चितं ब्रूहि तन्मे शिष्यस्तेऽहं शाधि मां त्वां प्रपन्नम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
kārpaṇya-dōṣō-pahat-asva-bhāvaḥ pṛcchāmi tvāṁ dharma-sammūḍha-cētāḥ |
yac-chrēyaḥ syān-niścitaṁ brūhi tan-mē śiṣyas-te-’haṁ śādhi māṁ tvāṁ prapannam ||

translations.english: My nature is afflicted by the weakness of compassion (kārpaṇya-dōṣa), and my mind is confused about my duty (dharma). I ask You—tell me decisively what is better for me. I am Your disciple; instruct me, who has taken refuge in You.

verses.original:
न हि प्रपश्यामि ममापनुद्याद् यच्छोकमुच्छोषणमिन्द्रियाणाम् ।
अवाप्य भूमावसपत्नमृद्धं राज्यं सुराणामपि चाधिपत्यम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
na hi prapaśyāmi mamāpanudyād yac-chōkam-ucchōṣaṇam-indriyāṇām |
avāpya bhūmāv-asapatnam-ṛddhaṁ rājyaṁ surāṇām-api cādhipatyam ||

translations.english: For I see no means to dispel this grief that is drying up my senses, even if I attain a prosperous, unrivaled kingdom on earth, or even sovereignty over the gods.

verses.original:
सञ्जय उवाच ।
एवमुक्त्वा हृषीकेशं गुडाकेशः परन्तप ।
न योत्स्य इति गोविन्दमुक्त्वा तूष्णीं बभूव ह ॥
verses.transliteration:
sañjaya uvāca |
ēvam-uktvā hṛṣīkēśaṁ guḍākēśaḥ parantapa |
na yōtsye iti gōvindam-uktvā tūṣṇīṁ babhūva ha ||

translations.english: Sanjaya said: Having spoken thus to Kṛṣṇa (Hṛṣīkēśa), Arjuna (Guḍākēśa), the scorcher of foes, said to Govinda, "I will not fight," and then fell silent.

verses.original:
तमुवाच हृषीकेशः प्रहसन्निव भारत ।
सेनयोरुभयोर्मध्ये विषीदन्तमिदं वचः ॥
verses.transliteration:
tam-uvāca hṛṣīkēśaḥ prahasann-iva bhārata |
senayōr-ubhayōr-madhye viṣīdantam-idaṁ vacaḥ ||

translations.english: O descendant of Bharata (Dhṛtarāṣṭra), Kṛṣṇa (Hṛṣīkēśa), as if smiling, spoke these words to the grieving Arjuna in the midst of the two armies.

verses.original:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
अशोच्यानन्वशोचस्त्वं प्रज्ञावादांश्च भाषसे ।
गतासूनगतासूंश्च नानुशोचन्ति पण्डिताः ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān-uvāca |
aśōcyān-anvaśōcas-tvaṁ prajñā-vādāṁśca bhāṣase |
gatāsūn-agatāsūṁś-ca nānuśōcanti paṇḍitāḥ ||

translations.english: The Supreme Lord said: You grieve for those who should not be grieved for, yet you speak words of wisdom. The wise neither grieve for the living nor for the dead.

verses.original:
न त्वेवाहं जातु नासं न त्वं नेमे जनाधिपाः ।
न चैव न भविष्यामः सर्वे वयमतः परम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
na tv-ēvāhaṁ jātu nāsaṁ na tvaṁ nēme janādhipāḥ |
na caiva na bhaviṣyāmaḥ sarvē vayam-ataḥ param ||

translations.english: There was never a time when I did not exist, nor you, nor these kings; nor will any of us cease to exist in the future.

verses.original:
देहिनोऽस्मिन्यथा देहे कौमारं यौवनं जरा ।
तथा देहान्तरप्राप्तिर्धीरस्तत्र न मुह्यति ॥
verses.transliteration:
dēhinō-’smin-yathā dēhē kaumāraṁ yauvanaṁ jarā |
tathā dēhāntara-prāptir-dhīras-tatra na muhyati ||

translations.english: Just as the embodied soul passes through childhood, youth, and old age in this body, similarly it passes into another body; the wise (dhīra) person is not bewildered by this.

verses.original:
मात्रास्पर्शास्तु कौन्तेय शीतोष्णसुखदुःखदाः ।
आगमापायिनोऽनित्यास्तांस्तितिक्षस्व भारत ॥
verses.transliteration:
mātrā-sparśās-tu kauntēya śītōṣṇa-sukha-duḥkhadāḥ |
āgam-āpāyinō-’nityās-tāṁs-titikṣasva bhārata ||

translations.english: O son of Kuntī, the contact of the senses with the objects produces cold and heat, pleasure and pain. They come and go, being temporary; endure them, O Bhārata.

verses.original:
यं हि न व्यथयन्त्येते पुरुषं पुरुषर्षभ ।
समदुःखसुखं धीरं सोऽमृतत्वाय कल्पते ॥
verses.transliteration:
yaṁ hi na vyathayanty-ēte puruṣaṁ puruṣarṣabha |
sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ dhīraṁ sō-’mṛtatvāya kalpate ||

translations.english: O best among men (Puruṣarṣabha), the person who is not disturbed by these—who is steady in pain and pleasure (sama-duḥkha-sukhaṁ)—that wise one (dhīra) is fit for immortality (amṛtatvāya).

verses.original:
नासतो विद्यते भावो नाभावो विद्यते सतः ।
उभयोरपि दृष्टोऽन्तस्त्वनयोस्तत्त्वदर्शिभिः ॥
verses.transliteration:
nāsatō vidyate bhāvo nābhāvō vidyate sataḥ |
ubhayōr-api dṛṣṭō-’ntas-tv-anayōs-tattva-darśibhiḥ ||

translations.english: Of the non-existent (asat), there is no being; of the existent (sat), there is no non-being. The true conclusion regarding both has been observed by the seers of truth (tattva-darśibhiḥ).

verses.original:
अविनाशि तु तद्विद्धि येन सर्वमिदं ततम् ।
विनाशमव्ययस्यास्य न कश्चित्कर्तुमर्हति ॥
verses.transliteration:
avināśi tu tad-viddhi yena sarvam-idaṁ tatam |
vināśam-avyayasy-āsya na kaścit-kartum-arhati ||

translations.english: Know that to be indestructible (avināśi) by which this entire universe is pervaded. No one can cause the destruction of that immutable being.

verses.original:
अन्तवन्त इमे देहा नित्यस्योक्ताः शरीरिणः ।
अनाशिनोऽप्रमेयस्य तस्माद्युध्यस्व भारत ॥
verses.transliteration:
antavanta ime dēhā nityasy-ōktāḥ śarīriṇaḥ |
anāśinō-’prameyasya tasmād-yudhyasva bhārata ||

translations.english: These bodies are said to belong to the eternal, indestructible, and immeasurable embodied soul (śarīriṇaḥ). Therefore, fight, O Bhārata.

verses.original:
य एनं वेत्ति हन्तारं यश्चैनं मन्यते हतम् ।
उभौ तौ न विजानीतो नायं हन्ति न हन्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
ya ēnaṁ vetti hantāraṁ yaś-cainaṁ manyate hatam |
ubhau tau na vijānītō nāyaṁ hanti na hanyate ||

translations.english: He who thinks the soul is the killer, and he who thinks the soul is killed—both of them are ignorant. The soul neither kills nor is killed.

verses.original:
न जायते म्रियते वा कदाचिन् नायं भूत्वा भविता वा न भूयः ।
अजो नित्यः शाश्वतोऽयं पुराणो न हन्यते हन्यमाने शरीरे ॥
verses.transliteration:
na jāyate mriyate vā kadācin nāyaṁ bhūtvā bhavitā vā na bhūyaḥ |
ajō nityaḥ śāśvatō-’yaṁ purāṇō na hanyate hanyamānē śarīrē ||

translations.english: The soul is neither born nor does it ever die; nor, having once existed, does it ever cease to be. The soul is unborn, eternal, everlasting, and ancient; it is not killed when the body is killed.

verses.original:
वेदाविनाशिनं नित्यं य एनमजमव्ययम् ।
कथं स पुरुषः पार्थ कं घातयति हन्ति कम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
vēdāvināśinaṁ nityaṁ ya ēnam-ajam-avyayam |
kathaṁ sa puruṣaḥ pārtha kaṁ ghātayati hanti kam ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā, how can that person who knows the soul to be indestructible, eternal, unborn, and immutable, kill anyone or cause anyone to be killed?

verses.original:
वासांसि जीर्णानि यथा विहाय नवानि गृह्णाति नरोऽपराणि ।
तथा शरीराणि विहाय जीर्णान्यन्यानि संयाति नवानि देही ॥
verses.transliteration:
vāsāṁsi jīrṇāni yathā vihāya navāni gṛhṇāti narō-’parāṇi |
tathā śarīrāṇi vihāya jīrṇāny-anyāni saṁyāti navāni dēhī ||

translations.english: Just as a person casts off worn-out clothes and puts on new ones, similarly, the embodied soul casts off worn-out bodies and enters into others that are new.

verses.original:
नैनं छिन्दन्ति शस्त्राणि नैनं दहति पावकः ।
न चैनं क्लेदयन्त्यापो न शोषयति मारुतः ॥
verses.transliteration:
nainaṁ chindanti śastrāṇi nainaṁ dahati pāvakaḥ |
na cainaṁ klēdayanty-āpō na śōṣayati mārutaḥ ||

translations.english: Weapons cannot cut the soul, nor can fire burn it; water cannot wet it, nor can the wind dry it.

verses.original:
अच्छेद्योऽयमदाह्योऽयमक्लेद्योऽशोष्य एव च ।
नित्यः सर्वगतः स्थाणुरचलोऽयं सनातनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
acchedyō-’yam-adāhyō-’yam-aklēdyō-’śōṣya ēva ca |
nityaḥ sarva-gataḥ sthāṇur-acalō-’yaṁ sanātanaḥ ||

translations.english: The soul is uncleavable, incombustible, incapable of being wetted or dried. It is eternal, all-pervading (sarva-gataḥ), unmoving (sthāṇu), immovable (acala), and everlasting (sanātanaḥ).

verses.original:
अव्यक्तोऽयमचिन्त्योऽयमविकार्योऽयमुच्यते ।
तस्मादेवं विदित्वैनं नानुशोचितुमर्हसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
avyaktō-’yam-acintyō-’yam-avikāryō-’yam-ucyate |
tasmād-ēvaṁ viditvainam n-ānuśōcitum-arhasi ||

translations.english: The soul is said to be unmanifest (avyakta), unthinkable (acintya), and unchangeable (avikārya). Therefore, knowing it to be so, you should not grieve.

verses.original:
अथ चैनं नित्यजातं नित्यं वा मन्यसे मृतम् ।
तथापि त्वं महाबाहो नैनं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
atha cainaṁ nitya-jātaṁ nityaṁ vā manyase mṛtam |
tathāpi tvaṁ mahābāhō nainam śōcitum-arhasi ||

translations.english: But even if you think the soul is continually born and continually dies, even then, O mighty-armed (Mahābāho), you should not grieve.

verses.original:
जातस्य हि ध्रुवो मृत्युर्ध्रुवं जन्म मृतस्य च ।
तस्मादपरिहार्येऽर्थे न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
jātasya hi dhruvō mṛtyur-dhruvaṁ janma mṛtasya ca |
tasmād-aparibhāryē-’rthē na tvaṁ śōcitum-arhasi ||

translations.english: For death is certain for one who is born, and rebirth is certain for one who dies. Therefore, you should not grieve over the inevitable.

verses.original:
अव्यक्तादीनि भूतानि व्यक्तमध्यानि भारत ।
अव्यक्तनिधनान्येव तत्र का परिदेवना ॥
verses.transliteration:
avyaktādīni bhūtāni vyakta-madhyāni bhārata |
avyakta-nidhanāny-ēva tatra kā paridēvanā ||

translations.english: O Bhārata, all beings are unmanifest (avyakta) in their beginning, manifest in their middle state, and unmanifest again in their end. What is there to lament about?

verses.original:
आश्चर्यवत्पश्यति कश्चिदेनम् आश्चर्यवद्वदति तथैव चान्यः ।
आश्चर्यवच्चैनमन्यः शृणोति श्रुत्वाप्येनं वेद न चैव कश्चित् ॥
verses.transliteration:
āścaryavat-paśyati kaścid-ēnam āścaryavad-vadati tathaiva cānyaḥ |
āścaryavat-cainaṁ anyaḥ śṛṇōti śrutvāpy-ēnaṁ vēda na caiva kaścit ||

translations.english: Some look upon the soul as amazing, some speak of it as amazing, and others hear of it as amazing; yet even after hearing, no one truly knows it.

verses.original:
देही नित्यमवध्योऽयं देहे सर्वस्य भारत ।
तस्मात्सर्वाणि भूतानि न त्वं शोचितुमर्हसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
dēhī nityam-avadhyō-’yaṁ dēhē sarvasya bhārata |
tasmāt-sarvāṇi bhūtāni na tvaṁ śōcitum-arhasi ||

translations.english: O Bhārata, the embodied soul (dēhī) is eternally indestructible in the body of everyone. Therefore, you should not grieve for any living being.

verses.original:
स्वधर्ममपि चावेक्ष्य न विकम्पितुमर्हसि ।
धर्म्याद्धि युद्धाच्छ्रेयोऽन्यत्क्षत्रियस्य न विद्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
sva-dharmam-api cāvēkṣya na vikampitum-arhasi |
dharmyāddhi yuddhāc-chrēyō-’nyat-kṣatriyasya na vidyate ||

translations.english: Considering your own duty (sva-dharma), you should not waver. For a warrior (Kṣatriya), there is nothing better than a righteous fight.

verses.original:
यदृच्छया चोपपन्नं स्वर्गद्वारमपावृतम् ।
सुखिनः क्षत्रियाः पार्थ लभन्ते युद्धमीदृशम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadṛcchayā cōpapannaṁ svarga-dvāram-apāvṛtam |
sukhinaḥ kṣatriyāḥ pārtha labhante yuddham-īdṛśam ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā, happy are the Kṣatriyas who are presented with such an opportunity for battle, which comes unsought, opening the gates of heaven.

verses.original:
अथ चेत्त्वमिमं धर्म्यं सङ्ग्रामं न करिष्यसि ।
ततः स्वधर्मं कीर्तिं च हित्वा पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
atha cēt-tvam-imaṁ dharmyaṁ saṅgrāmaṁ na kariṣyasi |
tataḥ sva-dharmaṁ kīrtiṁ ca hitvā pāpam-avāpsyasi ||

translations.english: But if you do not fight this righteous battle, then you will incur sin by abandoning your duty (sva-dharma) and your fame.

verses.original:
अकीर्तिं चापि भूतानि कथयिष्यन्ति तेऽव्ययाम् ।
सम्भावितस्य चाकीर्तिर्मरणादतिरिच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
akīrtiṁ cāpi bhūtāni kathayiṣyanti tē-’vyayām |
sambhāvitasya cākīrtir-maraṇād-atiricyate ||

translations.english: People will forever recount your lasting infamy. For a respected man, dishonor is worse than death.

verses.original:
भयाद्रणादुपरतं मंस्यन्ते त्वां महारथाः ।
येषां च त्वं बहुमतो भूत्वा यास्यसि लाघवम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
bhayād-raṇād-uparatam maṁsyantē tvāṁ mahārathāḥ |
yēṣāṁ ca tvaṁ bahumatō bhūtvā yāsyasi lāghavam ||

translations.english: The great chariot warriors (Mahārathas) will think that you withdrew from battle out of fear, and those who held you in high esteem will treat you with contempt.

verses.original:
अवाच्यवादांश्च बहून् वदिष्यन्ति तवाहिताः ।
निन्दन्तस्तव सामर्थ्यं ततो दुःखतरं नु किम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
avācya-vādāṁśca bahūn vadiṣyanti tavāhitāḥ |
nindantas-tava sāmarthyaṁ tatō duḥkhataraṁ nu kim ||

translations.english: Your enemies will speak many unutterable words, mocking your ability. What could be more painful than that?

verses.original:
हतो वा प्राप्स्यसि स्वर्गं जित्वा वा भोक्ष्यसे महीम् ।
तस्मादुत्तिष्ठ कौन्तेय युद्धाय कृतनिश्चयः ॥
verses.transliteration:
hatō vā prāpsyasi svargaṁ jitvā vā bhōkṣyase mahīm |
tasmād-uttiṣṭha kauntēya yuddhāya kṛta-niścayaḥ ||

translations.english: If killed, you will attain heaven; if victorious, you will enjoy the earth. Therefore, arise, O son of Kuntī, resolved to fight.

verses.original:
सुखदुःखे समे कृत्वा लाभालाभौ जयाजयौ ।
ततो युद्धाय युज्यस्व नैवं पापमवाप्स्यसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
sukha-duḥkhē samē kṛtvā lābhālābhau jayājayau |
tatō yuddhāya yujyasva naivaṁ pāpam-avāpsyasi ||

translations.english: Treating pleasure and pain, gain and loss, victory and defeat as equal (samē), engage in battle. By doing so, you will not incur sin.

verses.original:
एषा तेऽभिहिता साङ्ख्ये बुद्धिर्योगे त्विमां शृणु ।
बुद्ध्या युक्तो यया पार्थ कर्मबन्धं प्रहास्यसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
ēṣā tē-’bhihitā sāṅkhyē buddhir-yōgē tv-imāṁ śṛṇu |
buddhyā yuktō yayā pārtha karma-bandhaṁ prahāsyasi ||

translations.english: The knowledge (buddhi) explained to you is according to Sāṅkhya (analytical philosophy). Now listen to the knowledge of Yoga (Karma Yoga), by which, O son of Pṛthā, you will break the bondage of action.

verses.original:
नेहाभिक्रमनाशोऽस्ति प्रत्यवायो न विद्यते ।
स्वल्पमप्यस्य धर्मस्य त्रायते महतो भयात् ॥
verses.transliteration:
nēhābhikrama-nāśō-’sti pratyavāyō na vidyate |
svalpam-apy-asya dharmasya trāyate mahatō bhayāt ||

translations.english: In this path (Karma Yoga), there is no loss of effort (abhikrama-nāśō), nor is there any adverse result (pratyavāyō). Even a little of this discipline protects one from the great fear (of repeated birth and death).

verses.original:
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिरेकेह कुरुनन्दन ।
बहुशाखा ह्यनन्ताश्च बुद्धयोऽव्यवसायिनाम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
vyavasāyātmikā buddhir-ēkēha kuru-nandana |
bahu-śākhā hy-anantāśca buddhayō-’vyavasāyinām ||

translations.english: O beloved son of the Kurus (Kuru-nandana), the resolute intellect (vyavasāyātmikā buddhi) is focused and single-minded. The intellect of the irresolute (avyavasāyinām) is many-branched and endless.

verses.original:
यामिमां पुष्पितां वाचं प्रवदन्त्यविपश्चितः ।
वेदवादरताः पार्थ नान्यदस्तीति वादिनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yām-imāṁ puṣpitāṁ vācaṁ pravadanty-avipascitaḥ |
vēdavāda-ratāḥ pārtha nānyad-astīti vādinaḥ ||

translations.english: O Pārtha, those of small knowledge (avipascitaḥ) who delight in the literal word of the Vedas (Vēdavāda-ratāḥ) speak flowery words, saying there is nothing else.

verses.original:
कामात्मानः स्वर्गपरा जन्मकर्मफलप्रदाम् ।
क्रियाविशेषबहुलां भोगैश्वर्यगतिं प्रति ॥
verses.transliteration:
kāmātmānaḥ svarga-parā janma-karma-phala-pradām |
kriyā-viśēṣa-bahulāṁ bhōgaiśvarya-gatiṁ prati ||

translations.english: They are full of desires, aiming at heaven as the highest goal, whose actions result in rebirth, and who are obsessed with rituals for attaining pleasure and power.

verses.original:
भोगैश्वर्यप्रसक्तानां तयापहृतचेतसाम् ।
व्यवसायात्मिका बुद्धिः समाधौ न विधीयते ॥
verses.transliteration:
bhōgaiśvarya-prasaktānāṁ tayā-pahṛta-cētasām |
vyavasāyātmikā buddhiḥ samādhau na vidhīyate ||

translations.english: To those who are deeply attached to pleasure and power (bhōgaiśvarya) and whose minds are carried away by such words, the resolute intellect (vyavasāyātmikā buddhi) is not formed in concentration (samādhi).

verses.original:
त्रैगुण्यविषया वेदा निस्त्रैगुण्यो भवार्जुन ।
निर्द्वन्द्वो नित्यसत्त्वस्थो निर्योगक्षेम आत्मवान् ॥
verses.transliteration:
trai-guṇya-viṣayā vēdā nistrai-guṇyō bhavārjuna |
nir-dvandvō nitya-sattvasthō nir-yōgakṣēma ātmavān ||

translations.english: The Vedas deal with the three modes of nature (Trai-guṇya-viṣayā). O Arjuna, be free from the three modes, free from the dualities (nir-dvandvaḥ), eternally established in purity (nitya-sattvasthaḥ), free from acquisition and preservation (nir-yōgakṣēma), and established in the Self (ātmavān).

verses.original:
यावानर्थ उदपाने सर्वतः सम्प्लुतोदके ।
तावान्सर्वेषु वेदेषु ब्राह्मणस्य विजानतः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yāvān-artha udapānē sarvataḥ samplutōdake |
tāvān-sarvēṣu vēdēṣu brāhmaṇasya vijānataḥ ||

translations.english: The purpose served by a small well is also served by a large, fully flooded reservoir (samplutōdake). Similarly, the purpose of all the Vedas is served by a Brahmin (knower of Brahman) who possesses true knowledge.

verses.original:
कर्मण्येवाधिकारस्ते मा फलेषु कदाचन ।
मा कर्मफलहेतुर्भूर्मा ते सङ्गोऽस्त्वकर्मणि ॥
verses.transliteration:
karmaṇy-ēvādhi-kāras-te mā phalēṣu kadācana |
mā karma-phala-hētur-bhūr-mā tē saṅgō-’stvakarmaṇi ||

translations.english: Your right is only to perform your duty (karmaṇy-ēvādhi-kāraḥ), but never to the fruits of action (phalēṣu). Do not let the fruits of action be your motive, nor should you be attached to inaction (akarmaṇi).

verses.original:
योगस्थः कुरु कर्माणि सङ्गं त्यक्त्वा धनञ्जय ।
सिद्धयसिद्धयोः समो भूत्वा समत्वं योग उच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
yōga-sthaḥ kuru karmāṇi saṅgaṁ tyaktvā dhanañjaya |
siddhy-asiddhyōḥ samō bhūtvā samatvaṁ yōga ucyate ||

translations.english: Be steadfast in Yoga (yōga-sthaḥ), perform your duties, abandoning attachment (saṅgaṁ tyaktvā), O Dhanañjaya (Arjuna). Be balanced (samaḥ) in success and failure; such equipoise (samatvaṁ) is called Yoga.

verses.original:
दूरेण ह्यवरं कर्म बुद्धियोगाद्धनञ्जय ।
बुद्धौ शरणमन्विच्छ कृपणाः फलहेतवः ॥
verses.transliteration:
dūrēṇa hy-avaraṁ karma buddhi-yōgād-dhanañjaya |
buddhau śaraṇam-anviccha kṛpaṇāḥ phala-hētavaḥ ||

translations.english: Action motivated by results is far inferior to the Yoga of Intelligence (buddhi-yōgād), O Dhanañjaya. Seek refuge in wisdom; those who are motivated by fruits are miserable (kṛpaṇāḥ).

verses.original:
बुद्धियुक्तो जहातीह उभे सुकृतदुष्कृते ।
तस्माद्योगाय युज्यस्व योगः कर्मसु कौशलम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
buddhi-yuktō jahātīha ubhē sukṛta-duṣkṛte |
tasmād-yōgāya yujyasva yōgaḥ karmasu kauśalam ||

translations.english: The person endowed with wisdom (buddhi-yuktō) discards both good and bad deeds (sukṛta-duṣkṛte). Therefore, strive for Yoga, for Yoga is skill in action (karmasu kauśalam).

verses.original:
कर्मजं बुद्धियुक्ता हि फलं त्यक्त्वा मनीषिणः ।
जन्मबन्धविनिर्मुक्ताः पदं गच्छन्त्यनामयम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
karma-jaṁ buddhi-yuktā hi phalaṁ tyaktvā manīṣiṇaḥ |
janma-bandha-vinirmuktāḥ padaṁ gacchanty-anāmayam ||

translations.english: The wise (manīṣiṇaḥ), endowed with intelligence, renounce the fruit born of action and are freed from the bondage of birth (janma-bandha), reaching the state free from all misery.

verses.original:
यदा ते मोहकलिलं बुद्धिर्व्यतितरिष्यति ।
तदा गन्तासि निर्वेदं श्रोतव्यस्य श्रुतस्य च ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadā te mōha-kalilaṁ buddhir-vyatitariṣyati |
tadā gantāsi nir-vedaṁ śrōtavyasya śrutasya ca ||

translations.english: When your intellect (buddhi) completely crosses beyond the mire of delusion (mōha-kalilaṁ), then you will become indifferent to what has been heard and what is yet to be heard (scriptural injunctions).

verses.original:
श्रुतिविप्रतिपन्ना ते यदा स्थास्यति निश्चला ।
समाधावचला बुद्धिस्तदा योगमवाप्स्यसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
śruti-vipratipannā te yadā sthāsyati niścalā |
samādhāv-acalā buddhis-tadā yōgam-avāpsyasi ||

translations.english: When your intellect, which is confused by various scriptures, becomes steady and immovable in deep concentration (samādhi), then you will attain Yoga.

verses.original:
अर्जुन उवाच ।
स्थितप्रज्ञस्य का भाषा समाधिस्थस्य केशव ।
स्थितधीः किं प्रभाषेत किमासीत व्रजेत किम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvāca |
sthita-prajñasya kā bhāṣā samādhi-sthasya kēśava |
sthita-dhīḥ kiṁ prabhāṣēta kim-āsīta vrajēta kim ||

translations.english: Arjuna said: What is the description of a steady-minded person (sthita-prajñasya) absorbed in contemplation, O Keśava? How does the person of steady wisdom speak, how does he sit, and how does he walk?

verses.original:
श्रीभगवानुवाच ।
प्रजहाति यदा कामान्सर्वान्पार्थ मनोगतान् ।
आत्मन्येवात्मना तुष्टः स्थितप्रज्ञस्तदोच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
śrī-bhagavān-uvāca |
prajahāti yadā kāmān-sarvān-pārtha manō-gatān |
ātmany-ēvā-tmanā tuṣṭaḥ sthita-prajñas-tadōcyate ||

translations.english: The Supreme Lord said: When a man completely casts off all desires (kāmān) that enter the mind, O Pārtha, and is satisfied in the Self by the Self, then he is called one of steady wisdom (sthita-prajñaḥ).

verses.original:
दुःखेष्वनुद्विग्नमनाः सुखेषु विगतस्पृहः ।
वीतरागभयक्रोधः स्थितधीर्मुनिरुच्यते ॥
verses.transliteration:
duḥkhēṣv-an-udvigna-manāḥ sukhēṣu vigata-spṛhaḥ |
vīta-rāga-bhaya-krōdhaḥ sthita-dhīr-munir-ucyate ||

translations.english: He whose mind is undisturbed in sorrow (duḥkhēṣu), who has no craving for pleasures, and who is free from attachment, fear, and anger (vīta-rāga-bhaya-krōdhaḥ)—such a sage is called a person of steady wisdom (sthita-dhīḥ).

verses.original:
यः सर्वत्रानभिस्नेहस्तत्तत्प्राप्य शुभाशुभम् ।
नाभिनन्दति न द्वेष्टि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
verses.transliteration:
yaḥ sarvatrā-nabhisnēhas-tat-tat-prāpya śubhāśubham |
nābhinandati na dvēṣṭi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||

translations.english: He who is without attachment everywhere, and who, on receiving good or evil, neither rejoices nor hates—his wisdom (prajñā) is firmly established.

verses.original:
यदा संहरते चायं कूर्मोऽङ्गानीव सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadā saṁharate cāyaṁ kūrmō-’ṅgān-īva sarvaśaḥ |
indriyāṇ-īndriyā-rthēbhyas-tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||

translations.english: When, like a tortoise withdrawing its limbs from all sides, a person withdraws his senses from the objects of sense—his wisdom is firmly established.

verses.original:
विषया विनिवर्तन्ते निराहारस्य देहिनः ।
रसवर्जं रसोऽप्यस्य परं दृष्ट्वा निवर्तते ॥
verses.transliteration:
viṣayā vinivartantē nirāhārasya dehinaḥ |
rasa-varjaṁ rasō-’py-asya paraṁ dṛṣṭvā nivartate ||

translations.english: The objects of sense turn away from the embodied soul who abstains from feeding on them (nirāhārasya), but the taste (rasa) for them remains. Even the taste turns away when the Supreme (Paraṁ) is seen.

verses.original:
यततो ह्यपि कौन्तेय पुरुषस्य विपश्चितः ।
इन्द्रियाणि प्रमाथीनि हरन्ति प्रसभं मनः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yatatō hy-api kauntēya puruṣasya vipaścitaḥ |
indriyāṇi pramāthīni haranti prasabhaṁ manaḥ ||

translations.english: O son of Kuntī, the turbulent senses (indriyāṇi), even of a striving and discerning person, forcibly carry away the mind.

verses.original:
तानि सर्वाणि संयम्य युक्त आसीत मत्परः ।
वशे हि यस्येन्द्रियाणि तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
verses.transliteration:
tāni sarvāṇi saṁyamya yukta āsīta mat-paraḥ |
vaśe hi yasy-endriyāṇi tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||

translations.english: Having restrained all the senses, one should sit focused (yukta), intent on Me (mat-paraḥ). For the wisdom of one whose senses are under control is firmly established.

verses.original:
ध्यायतो विषयान्पुंसः सङ्गस्तेषूपजायते ।
सङ्गात्सञ्जायते कामः कामात्क्रोधोऽभिजायते ॥
verses.transliteration:
dhyāyatō viṣayān-puṁsaḥ saṅgas-tēṣū-pajāyate |
saṅgāt-sañjāyate kāmaḥ kāmāt-krōdhō-’bhijāyate ||

translations.english: When a man dwells on the objects of sense, attachment (saṅgaḥ) to them arises. From attachment arises desire (kāmaḥ), and from unfulfilled desire, anger (krōdhaḥ) is produced.

verses.original:
क्रोधाद्भवति सम्मोहः सम्मोहात्स्मृतिविभ्रमः ।
स्मृतिभ्रंशाद् बुद्धिनाशो बुद्धिनाशात्प्रणश्यति ॥
verses.transliteration:
krōdhād-bhavati sammōhaḥ sammōhāt-smṛti-vibhrāmaḥ |
smṛti-bhraṁśād buddhi-nāśō buddhi-nāśāt-praṇaśyati ||

translations.english: From anger comes delusion (sammōhaḥ); from delusion, loss of memory (smṛti-vibhrāmaḥ); from loss of memory, the destruction of intelligence (buddhi-nāśaḥ); and from the destruction of intelligence, one perishes (praṇaśyati).

verses.original:
रागद्वेषवियुक्तैस्तु विषयानिन्द्रियैश्चरन् ।
आत्मवश्यैर्विधेयात्मा प्रसादमधिगच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
rāga-dvēṣa-viyuktais-tu viṣayān-indriyaiś-caran |
ātma-vaśyair-vidhēy-ātmā prasādam-adhigacchati ||

translations.english: But the self-controlled person, moving among sense objects with senses free from attraction and aversion (rāga-dvēṣa-viyuktaiḥ) and under his own control, attains tranquility (prasādam).

verses.original:
प्रसादे सर्वदुःखानां हानिरस्योपजायते ।
प्रसन्नचेतसो ह्याशु बुद्धिः पर्यवतिष्ठते ॥
verses.transliteration:
prasādē sarva-duḥkhānāṁ hānir-asyō-pajāyate |
prasanna-cētasō hy-āśu buddhiḥ paryavatiṣṭhate ||

translations.english: In that tranquility, all sorrows cease, for the intellect of the tranquil-minded (prasanna-cētasō) soon becomes steady.

verses.original:
नास्ति बुद्धिरयुक्तस्य न चायुक्तस्य भावना ।
न चाभावयतः शान्तिरशान्तस्य कुतः सुखम् ॥
verses.transliteration:
nāsti buddhir-ayuktasya na cāyuktasya bhāvanā |
na cābhāvayataḥ śāntir-aśāntasya kutaḥ sukham ||

translations.english: There is no wisdom for the unsteady (ayuktasya), and no contemplation for the unsteady; for the un-contemplative, there is no peace, and for the peaceless, how can there be happiness?

verses.original:
इन्द्रियाणां हि चरतां यन्मनोऽनु विधीयते ।
तदस्य हरति प्रज्ञां वायुर्नावमिवाम्भसि ॥
verses.transliteration:
indriyāṇāṁ hi caratāṁ yan-manō-’nu vidhīyate |
tad-asya harati prajñāṁ vāyur-nāvam-ivāmbhasi ||

translations.english: For the mind that yields to the wandering senses (indriyāṇāṁ), that single sense carries away his wisdom (prajñā), just as the wind carries away a boat on the water.

verses.original:
तस्माद्यस्य महाबाहो निगृहीतानि सर्वशः ।
इन्द्रियाणीन्द्रियार्थेभ्यस्तस्य प्रज्ञा प्रतिष्ठिता ॥
verses.transliteration:
tasmād-yasya mahābāhō nigṛhītāni sarvaśaḥ |
indriyāṇ-īndriyā-rthēbhyas-tasya prajñā pratiṣṭhitā ||

translations.english: Therefore, O mighty-armed (Mahābāho), his wisdom is firmly established whose senses are completely restrained from the objects of the senses.

verses.original:
या निशा सर्वभूतानां तस्यां जागर्ति संयमी ।
यस्यां जाग्रति भूतानि सा निशा पश्यतो मुनेः ॥
verses.transliteration:
yā niśā sarva-bhūtānāṁ tasyāṁ jāgarti saṁyamī |
yasyāṁ jāgrati bhūtāni sā niśā paśyatō muneḥ ||

translations.english: What is night (niśā) for all beings, the self-controlled person (saṁyamī) is awake therein; and that in which all beings are awake, that is night for the discerning sage (muneḥ).

verses.original:
आपूर्यमाणमचलप्रतिष्ठं समुद्रमापः प्रविशन्ति यद्वत् ।
तद्वत्कामा यं प्रविशन्ति सर्वे स शान्तिमाप्नोति न कामकामी ॥
verses.transliteration:
āpūryamāṇam-acala-pratiṣṭhaṁ samudram-āpaḥ praviśanti yadvat |
tadvat-kāmā yaṁ praviśanti sarvē sa śāntim-āpnōti na kāma-kāmī ||

translations.english: Just as the waters enter the ocean, which remains unmoved (acala-pratiṣṭhaṁ) even when filled from all sides, so does the person attain peace into whom all desires (kāmā) enter, and not the one who craves desires.

verses.original:
विहाय कामान्यः सर्वान्पुमांश्चरति निःस्पृहः ।
निर्ममो निरहङ्कारः स शान्तिमधिगच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
vihāya kāmān-yaḥ sarvān-pumāṁś-carati niḥspṛhaḥ |
nirmamō nirahankāraḥ sa śāntim-adhigacchati ||

translations.english: The person who gives up all desires, who acts free from longing (niḥspṛhaḥ), without the sense of "I" and "mine" (nirmamō nirahankāraḥ), attains peace (śāntim).

verses.original:
एषा ब्राह्मी स्थितिः पार्थ नैनां प्राप्य विमुह्यति ।
स्थित्वास्यामन्तकालेऽपि ब्रह्मनिर्वाणमृच्छति ॥
verses.transliteration:
ēṣā brāhmī sthitiḥ pārtha naināṁ prāpya vimuhyati |
sthitvāsyām-anta-kālē-’pi brahma-nirvāṇam-ṛcchati ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā, this is the divine state (brāhmī sthitiḥ). Having attained this, one is not again bewildered. Becoming established in this state even at the hour of death, one attains liberation in Brahman (brahma-nirvāṇam).

chapters.name: Karma Yoga: The Yoga of Action
chapters.summary: Krishna explains that action is inevitable for all beings and that the true path lies in performing prescribed duties without attachment to the results, dedicating all actions to the Supreme.

verses.original:
अर्जुन उवाच
ज्यायसी चेत्कर्मणस्ते मता बुद्धिर्जनार्दन ।
तत्किं कर्मणि घोरे मां नियोजयसि केशव ॥ १ ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
jyāyasī chet karmaṇas te matā buddhir janārdana |
tat kiṁ karmaṇi ghore māṁ niyojayasi keśhava || 1 ||

translations.english: Arjuna said: O Janārdana (Krishna), if You consider intelligence (knowledge) to be superior to action, why then do you urge me to engage in this dreadful action, O Keśhava (Krishna)?

verses.original:
व्यामिश्रेणेव वाक्येन बुद्धिं मोहयसीव मे ।
तदेकं वद निश्चित्य येन श्रेयोऽहमाप्नुयाम् ॥ २ ॥
verses.transliteration:
vyāmiśhreṇeva vākyena buddhiṁ mohayasīva me |
tad ekaṁ vada niśhchitya yena śhreyo 'ham āpnuyām || 2 ||

translations.english: My intelligence is bewildered by your seemingly contradictory instructions. Therefore, please tell me decisively that one path by which I may attain the highest good.

verses.original:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
लोकेऽस्मिन्द्विविधा निष्ठा पुरा प्रोक्ता मयानघ ।
ज्ञानयोगेन साङ्ख्यानां कर्मयोगेन योगिनाम् ॥ ३ ॥
verses.transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
loke 'smin dvi-vidhā niṣhṭhā purā proktā mayānagha |
jñāna-yogena sāṅkhyānāṁ karma-yogena yoginām || 3 ||

translations.english: The Supreme Lord said: O sinless one, a two-fold path for spiritual progress was previously explained by Me in this world—the path of knowledge (Jñāna Yoga) for those inclined toward contemplation, and the path of action (Karma Yoga) for those inclined toward work.

verses.original:
न कर्मणामनारम्भान्नैष्कर्म्यं पुरुषोऽश्नुते ।
न च सन्न्यसनादेव सिद्धिं समधिगच्छति ॥ ४ ॥
verses.transliteration:
na karmaṇām anārambhān naiṣhkarmyaṁ puruṣho 'śhnute |
na cha sannyasanād eva siddhiṁ samadhigachchhati || 4 ||

translations.english: A person does not achieve freedom from reaction by merely abstaining from work, nor does one attain perfection simply by renunciation.

verses.original:
न हि कश्चित्क्षणमपि जातु तिष्ठत्यकर्मकृत् ।
कार्यते ह्यवशः कर्म सर्वः प्रकृतिजैर्गुणैः ॥ ५ ॥
verses.transliteration:
na hi kaśhchit kṣhaṇam api jātu tiṣhṭhaty akarma-kṛt |
kāryate hy avaśhaḥ karma sarvaḥ prakṛti-jair guṇaiḥ || 5 ||

translations.english: No one can remain without action even for a moment. Indeed, all living beings are compelled to act by the qualities born of material nature (the guṇas).

verses.original:
कर्मेन्द्रियाणि संयम्य य आस्ते मनसा स्मरन् ।
इन्द्रियार्थान्विमूढात्मा मिथ्याचारः स उच्यते ॥ ६ ॥
verses.transliteration:
karmendriyāṇi saṁyamya ya āste manasā smaran |
indriyārthān vimūḍhātmā mithyāchāraḥ sa uchyate || 6 ||

translations.english: One who restrains the organs of action but continues to dwell on the objects of the senses in the mind, such a deluded person is called a hypocrite.

verses.original:
यस्त्विन्द्रियाणि मनसा नियम्यारभतेऽर्जुन ।
कर्मेन्द्रियैः कर्मयोगमसक्तः स विशिष्यते ॥ ७ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yas tv indriyāṇi manasā niyamyārabhate 'rjuna |
karmendriyaiḥ karma-yogam asaktaḥ sa viśiṣhyate || 7 ||

translations.english: But, O Arjuna, one who controls the senses with the mind and engages the organs of action in the Yoga of action (Karma Yoga), without attachment, is superior.

verses.original:
नियतं कुरु कर्म त्वं कर्म ज्यायो ह्यकर्मणः ।
शरीरयात्रापि च ते न प्रसिद्ध्येदकर्मणः ॥ ८ ॥
verses.transliteration:
niyataṁ kuru karma tvaṁ karma jyāyo hy akarmaṇaḥ |
śharīra-yātrāpi cha te na prasiddhyed akarmaṇaḥ || 8 ||

translations.english: Perform your prescribed duty, for action is superior to inaction. Even the maintenance of your body would not be possible if you remain inactive.

verses.original:
यज्ञार्थात्कर्मणोऽन्यत्र लोकोऽयं कर्मबन्धनः ।
तदर्थं कर्म कौन्तेय मुक्तसङ्गः समाचर ॥ ९ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yajñārthāt karmaṇo 'nyatra loko 'yaṁ karma-bandhanaḥ |
tad-arthaṁ karma kaunteya mukta-saṅgaḥ samāchara || 9 ||

translations.english: Work done as a sacrifice (Yajña) for Vishnu (or God) must be performed; otherwise, action causes bondage in this world. Therefore, O son of Kunti, perform your prescribed duties efficiently, without being attached to the results.

verses.original:
सहयज्ञाः प्रजाः सृष्ट्वा पुरोवाच प्रजापतिः ।
अनेन प्रसविष्यध्वमेष वोऽस्त्विष्टकामधुक् ॥ १० ॥
verses.transliteration:
saha-yajñāḥ prajāḥ sṛṣhṭvā purovācha prajāpatiḥ |
anena prasaviṣhyadhvam eṣha vo 'stv iṣhṭa-kāma-dhuk || 10 ||

translations.english: In the beginning, Prajāpati (the Creator) created mankind along with the performance of sacrifice (Yajña), and said: 'By this (Yajña) you will multiply. Let this be the fulfiller of all your desires.'

verses.original:
देवान्भावयतानेन ते देवा भावयन्तु वः ।
परस्परं भावयन्तः श्रेयः परमवाप्स्यथ ॥ ११ ॥
verses.transliteration:
devān bhāvayatānena te devā bhāvayantu vaḥ |
parasparaṁ bhāvayantaḥ śhreyaḥ param avāpsyatha || 11 ||

translations.english: Nourish the celestial beings (devas) with this sacrifice, and let those devas nourish you. Thus, nurturing one another, you will attain the highest good.

verses.original:
इष्टान्भोगान्हि वो देवा दास्यन्ते यज्ञभाविताः ।
तैर्दत्तानप्रदायैभ्यो यो भुङ्क्ते स्तेन एव सः ॥ १२ ॥
verses.transliteration:
iṣhṭān bhogān hi vo devā dāsyante yajña-bhāvitāḥ |
tair dattān apradāyaibhyo yo bhuṅkte stena eva saḥ || 12 ||

translations.english: Nourished by sacrifice, the celestial beings will indeed grant you the desired enjoyments. He who enjoys the gifts given by them without offering anything in return is verily a thief.

verses.original:
यज्ञशिष्टाशिनः सन्तो मुच्यन्ते सर्वकिल्बिषैः ।
भुञ्जते ते त्वघं पापा ये पचन्त्यात्मककारणत् ॥ १३ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yajña-śhiṣhṭāśinaḥ santo muchyante sarva-kilbiṣhaiḥ |
bhuñjate te tv aghaṁ pāpā ye pachanty ātma-kāraṇāt || 13 ||

translations.english: The righteous who eat the remnants of the sacrifice are freed from all kinds of sins, but those who cook for their own enjoyment verily eat only sin.

verses.original:
अन्नाद्भवन्ति भूतानि पर्जन्यादन्नसम्भवः ।
यज्ञाद्भवति पर्जन्यो यज्ञः कर्मसमुद्भवः ॥ १४ ॥
verses.transliteration:
annād bhavanti bhūtāni parjanyād anna-sambhavaḥ |
yajñād bhavati parjanyo yajñaḥ karma-samudbhavaḥ || 14 ||

translations.english: All living beings subsist on food, which is produced from rain. Rain comes from the performance of sacrifice, and sacrifice is born of prescribed duties (action).

verses.original:
कर्म ब्रह्मोद्भवं विद्धि ब्रह्माक्षरसमुद्भवम् ।
तस्मात्सर्वगतं ब्रह्म नित्यं यज्ञे प्रतिष्ठितम् ॥ १५ ॥
verses.transliteration:
karma brahmodbhavaṁ viddhi brahmākṣhara-samudbhavam |
tasmāt sarva-gataṁ brahma nityaṁ yajñe pratiṣhṭhitam || 15 ||

translations.english: Know that action (karma) originates from the Vedas (Brahman), and the Vedas originate from the Imperishable (Akṣhara). Therefore, the all-pervading Brahman is eternally established in acts of sacrifice.

verses.original:
एवं प्रवर्तितं चक्रं नानुवर्तयतीह यः ।
अघायुरिन्द्रियारामो मोघं पार्थ स जीवति ॥ १६ ॥
verses.transliteration:
evaṁ pravartitaṁ chakraṁ nānuvartayatīha yaḥ |
aghāyur indriyārāmo moghaṁ pārtha sa jīvati || 16 ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā, one who does not follow the wheel of sacrifice thus set in motion in this world, and who leads a sinful life, indulging in the senses, lives in vain.

verses.original:
यस्त्वात्मरतिरेव स्यादात्मतृप्तश्च मानवः ।
आत्मन्येव च सन्तुष्टस्तस्य कार्यं न विद्यते ॥ १७ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yas tv ātma-ratir eva syād ātma-tṛptaśh cha mānavaḥ |
ātmani eva cha santuṣhṭas tasya kāryaṁ na vidyate || 17 ||

translations.english: But for the person who takes delight only in the Self, is satisfied with the Self, and is content in the Self alone, there is no work to be done.

verses.original:
नैव तस्य कृतेनार्थो नाकृतेनेह कश्चन ।
न चास्य सर्वभूतेषु कश्चिदर्थव्यपाश्रयः ॥ १८ ॥
verses.transliteration:
naiva tasya kṛtenārtho nā 'kṛteneha kaśhchana |
na chāsya sarva-bhūteṣhu kaśchid artha-vyapāśhrayaḥ || 18 ||

translations.english: For him, there is no interest whatsoever in what has been done or in what has not been done; nor does he depend on any other living being for any purpose.

verses.original:
तस्मादसक्तः सततं कार्यं कर्म समाचर ।
असक्तो ह्याचरन्कर्म परमाप्नोति पूरुषः ॥ १९ ॥
verses.transliteration:
tasmād asaktaḥ satataṁ kāryaṁ karma samāchara |
asakto hy ācharan karma param āpnoti pūruṣhaḥ || 19 ||

translations.english: Therefore, constantly perform your duty without attachment, for by working without attachment, one attains the Supreme.

verses.original:
कर्मणैव हि संसिद्धिमास्थिता जनकादयः ।
लोकसंग्रहमेवापि सम्पश्यन्कर्तुमर्हसि ॥ २० ॥
verses.transliteration:
karmaṇaiva hi saṁsiddhim āsthitā janakādayaḥ |
loka-saṅgraham evāpi sampaśhyan kartum arhasi || 20 ||

translations.english: Indeed, King Janaka and others attained perfection merely by performance of prescribed duties. Therefore, you should also perform work, keeping in view the welfare and guidance of the people.

verses.original:
यद्यदाचरति श्रेष्ठस्तत्तदेवेतरो जनः ।
स यत्प्रमाणं कुरुते लोकस्तदनुवर्तते ॥ २१ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yad yad ācharati śhreṣhṭhas tat tad evetaro janaḥ |
sa yat pramāṇaṁ kurute lokas tad anuvartate || 21 ||

translations.english: Whatever a great person does, others follow. Whatever standard he sets by his actions, the world follows that.

verses.original:
न मे पार्थास्ति कर्तव्यं त्रिषु लोकेषु किञ्चन ।
नानवप्तमवाप्तव्यं वर्त एव च कर्मणि ॥ २२ ॥
verses.transliteration:
na me pārthāsti kartavyaṁ triṣhu lokeṣhu kiñchana |
nānavāptam avāptavyaṁ varta eva cha karmaṇi || 22 ||

translations.english: O son of Pṛthā, I have no prescribed duty in all the three worlds, nor do I have anything to gain or attain. Yet, I am engaged in prescribed duties.

verses.original:
यदि ह्यहं न वर्तेयं जातु कर्मण्यतन्द्रितः ।
मम वर्त्मानुवर्तन्ते मनुष्याः पार्थ सर्वशः ॥ २३ ॥
verses.transliteration:
yadi hy ahaṁ na varteyaṁ jātu karmaṇy atandritaḥ |
mama vartmānuvartante manuṣhyāḥ pārtha sarvaśhaḥ || 23 ||

translations.english: For if I did not carefully perform my prescribed duties, O son of Pṛthā, all men would follow My path in all respects.

verses.original:
उत्सीदेयुरिमे लोका न कुर्यां कर्म चेदहम् ।
सङ्करस्य च कर्ता स्यामुपहन्यामिमाः प्रजाः ॥ २४ ॥
verses.transliteration:
utsīdeyur ime lokā na kuryāṁ karma ched aham |
saṅkarasya cha kartā syām upahanyām imāḥ prajāḥ || 24 ||

translations.english: If I were not to perform action, these worlds would be destroyed. I would be the cause of creating unwanted population (saṅkara), and I would thereby destroy the peace of all living beings.

verses.original:
सक्ताः कर्मण्यविद्वांसो यथा कुर्वन्ति भारत ।
कुर्याद्विद्वांस्तथासक्तश्चिकीर्षुर्लोकसंग्रहम् ॥ २५ ॥
verses.transliteration:
saktāḥ karmaṇy avidvāṁso yathā kurvanti bhārata |
kuryād vidvāṁs tathāsaktaśh chikīrṣhur loka-saṅgraham || 25 ||

translations.english: As the ignorant perform their duties with attachment to the results, O scion of Bharata, so should the wise act without attachment, but with the desire to guide the people.

verses.original:
न बुद्धिभेदं जनयेदज्ञानां कर्मसङ्गिनाम् ।
जोषयेत्सर्वकर्माणि विद्वान् युक्तः समाचरन् ॥ २६ ॥
verses.transliteration:
na buddhi-bhedaṁ janayed ajñānāṁ karma-saṅginām |
joṣhayet sarva-karmāṇi vidvān yuktaḥ samācharan || 26 ||

translations.english: The wise person should not create confusion in the minds of the ignorant, who are attached to fruitive action. Rather, by performing actions in a spirit of devotion (Yoga), he should inspire them to do the same.

verses.original:
प्रकृतेः क्रियमाणानि गुणैः कर्माणि सर्वशः ।
अहङ्कारविमूढात्मा कर्ताहमिति मन्यते ॥ २७ ॥
verses.transliteration:
prakṛteḥ kriyamāṇāni guṇaiḥ karmāṇi sarvaśhaḥ |
ahaṅkāra-vimūḍhātmā kartāham iti manyate || 27 ||

translations.english: All actions are performed by the qualities (guṇas) of material nature. The deluded soul, bewildered by false ego (ahaṅkāra), thinks, 'I am the doer.'

verses.original:
तत्त्ववित्तु महाबाहो गुणकर्मविभागयोः ।
गुणा गुणेषु वर्तन्त इति मत्वा न सज्जते ॥ २८ ॥
verses.transliteration:
tattva-vit tu mahā-bāho guṇa-karma-vibhāgayoḥ |
guṇā guṇeṣhu vartanta iti matvā na sajjate || 28 ||

translations.english: But he who is a knower of the truth, O mighty-armed one, knows that the senses engage the objects of the senses, and is therefore not attached to the actions.

verses.original:
प्रकृतेर्गुणसम्मूढाः सज्जन्ते गुणकर्मसु ।
तानकृत्स्नविदो मन्दान्कृत्स्नविन्न विचालयेत् ॥ २९ ॥
verses.transliteration:
prakṛter guṇa-sammūḍhāḥ sajjante guṇa-karmasu |
tān akṛtsna-vido mandān kṛtsna-vin na vichālayet || 29 ||

translations.english: Those bewildered by the qualities of material nature become attached to the actions and results of the qualities. The wise man should not unsettle these unintelligent persons who have imperfect knowledge.

verses.original:
मयि सर्वाणि कर्माणि सन्न्यस्याध्यात्मचेतसा ।
निराशीर्निर्ममो भूत्वा युध्यस्व विगतज्वरः ॥ ३० ॥
verses.transliteration:
mayi sarvāṇi karmāṇi sannyasyādhyātma-chetasā |
nirāśhīr nirmamo bhūtvā yudhyasva vigata-jvaraḥ || 30 ||

translations.english: Dedicating all your actions to Me, with your mind focused on the Self, free from desires and possessiveness, fight, without any fever of the mind.

verses.original:
ये मे मतमिदं नित्यमनुतिष्ठन्ति मानवाः ।
श्रद्धावन्तोऽनसूयन्तो मुच्यन्ते तेऽपि कर्मभिः ॥ ३१ ॥
verses.transliteration:
ye me matam idaṁ nityam anutiṣhṭhanti mānavāḥ |
śhraddhāvanto 'nasūyanto muchyante te 'pi karmabhiḥ || 31 ||

translations.english: Those human beings who constantly follow this teaching of Mine with faith and without envy are freed from the bondage of actions.

verses.original:
ये त्वेतदभ्यसूयन्तो नानुतिष्ठन्ति मे मतम् ।
सर्वज्ञानविमूढांस्तान्विद्धि नष्टानचेतसः ॥ ३२ ॥
verses.transliteration:
ye tv etad abhyasūyanto nānutiṣhṭhanti me matam |
sarva-jñāna-vimūḍhāṁs tān viddhi naṣhṭān achetasaḥ || 32 ||

translations.english: But know that those who, out of envy, disregard this teaching of Mine and do not follow it, are senseless, bewildered in all knowledge, and doomed to ruin.

verses.original:
सदृशं चेष्टते स्वस्याः प्रकृतेर्ज्ञानवानपि ।
प्रकृतिं यान्ति भूतानि निग्रहः किं करिष्यति ॥ ३३ ॥
verses.transliteration:
sadṛśhaṁ cheṣhṭate svasyāḥ prakṛter jñānavān api |
prakṛtiṁ yānti bhūtāni nigrahaḥ kiṁ kariṣhyati || 33 ||

translations.english: Even the wise man acts according to his own nature, for all living beings follow their nature. What can restraint accomplish?

verses.original:
इन्द्रियस्येन्द्रियस्यार्थे रागद्वेषौ व्यवस्थितौ ।
तयोर्न वशमागच्छेत्तौ ह्यस्य परिपन्थिनौ ॥ ३४ ॥
verses.transliteration:
indriyasyendriyasyārthe rāga-dveṣhau vyavasthitau |
tayor na vaśam āgachchhet tau hy asya paripanthinau || 34 ||

translations.english: Attachment and aversion for the objects of the senses are inherent in the senses. One should not come under the control of these two, for they are obstacles on the path.

verses.original:
श्रेयान्स्वधर्मो विगुणः परधर्मात्स्वनुष्ठितात् ।
स्वधर्मे निधनं श्रेयः परधर्मो भयावहः ॥ ३५ ॥
verses.transliteration:
śhreyān sva-dharmo viguṇaḥ para-dharmāt su-anuṣhṭhitāt |
sva-dharme nidhanaṁ śhreyaḥ para-dharmo bhayāvahaḥ || 35 ||

translations.english: It is far better to perform one's own prescribed duty, though imperfectly, than to perform another's duty perfectly. Death in the discharge of one's own duty is better; to follow the path of another is fraught with danger.

verses.original:
अर्जुन उवाच
अथ केन प्रयुक्तोऽयं पापं चरति पूरुषः ।
अनिच्छन्नपि वार्ष्णेय बलादिव नियोजितः ॥ ३६ ॥
verses.transliteration:
arjuna uvācha
atha kena prayukto 'yaṁ pāpaṁ charati pūruṣhaḥ |
anichchhann api vārṣhṇeya balād iva niyojitaḥ || 36 ||

translations.english: Arjuna said: O descendant of Vṛṣṇi (Krishna), what is it that impels a person to commit sin, even unwillingly, as if by force?

verses.original:
श्रीभगवानुवाच
काम एष क्रोध एष रजोगुणसमुद्भवः ।
महाशनो महापाप्मा विद्ध्येनमिह वैरिणम् ॥ ३७ ॥
verses.transliteration:
śhrī bhagavān uvācha
kāma eṣha krodha eṣha rajo-guṇa-samudbhavaḥ |
mahāśhano mahā-pāpmā viddhy enam iha vairiṇam || 37 ||

translations.english: The Supreme Lord said: It is **lust** (desire)—which transforms into **wrath**—born of the passion-element (**rajo-guṇa**). Know this all-devouring, greatly sinful enemy to be the great foe in this world.

verses.original:
धूमेनाव्रियते वह्निर्यथादर्शो मलेन च ।
यथोल्बेनावृतो गर्भस्तथा तेनेदमावृतम् ॥ ३८ ॥
verses.transliteration:
dhūmenāvriyate vahnir yathādarśho malena cha |
yatholbenāvṛto garbhas tathā tenedam āvṛtam || 38 ||

translations.english: Just as fire is covered by smoke, a mirror by dust, or an embryo by the womb, so is this knowledge (of the Self) covered by that desire (lust).

verses.original:
आवृतं ज्ञानमेतेन ज्ञानिनो नित्यवैरिणा ।
कामरूपेण कौन्तेय दुष्पूरेणानलेन च ॥ ३९ ॥
verses.transliteration:
āvṛtaṁ jñānam etena jñānino nitya-vairiṇā |
kāma-rūpeṇa kaunteya duṣhpūreṇānalena cha || 39 ||

translations.english: O son of Kunti, the knowledge of the wise is covered by this eternal enemy in the form of desire, which is insatiable like a fire.

verses.original:
इन्द्रियाणि मनो बुद्धिरस्याधिष्ठानमुच्यते ।
एतैर्विमोहयत्येष ज्ञानमावृत्य देहिनम् ॥ ४० ॥
verses.transliteration:
indriyāṇi mano buddhir asyādhiṣhṭhānam uchyate |
etair vimohayaty eṣha jñānam āvṛtya dehinam || 40 ||

translations.english: The senses, the mind, and the intellect are said to be the seat of this desire. Covering the knowledge of the embodied soul by these, it bewilders him.

verses.original:
तस्मात्त्वमिन्द्रियाण्यादौ नियम्य भरतर्षभ ।
पाप्मानं प्रजहि ह्येनं ज्ञानविज्ञाननाशनम् ॥ ४ १ ॥
verses.transliteration:
tasmāt tvam indriyāṇy ādau niyamya bharatarṣhabha |
pāpmānaṁ prajahi hy enaṁ jñāna-vijñāna-nāśhanam || 41 ||

translations.english: Therefore, O best of the Bharatas, first control your senses and slay this sinful enemy of desire, which destroys both knowledge (jñāna) and realization (vijñāna).

verses.original:
इन्द्रियाणि पराण्याहुरिन्द्रियेभ्यः परं मनः ।
मनसस्तु परा बुद्धिर्यो बुद्धेः परतस्तु सः ॥ ४२ ॥
verses.transliteration:
indriyāṇi parāṇy āhur indriyebhyaḥ paraṁ manaḥ |
manasas tu parā buddhir yo buddheḥ paratas tu saḥ || 42 ||

translations.english: The senses are superior to the gross body, the mind is superior to the senses, the intellect is superior to the mind, and the Self (the soul) is superior to the intellect.

verses.original:
एवं बुद्धेः परं बुद्ध्वा संस्तभ्यात्मानमात्मना ।
जहि शत्रुं महाबाहो कामरूपं दुरासदम् ॥ ४३ ॥
verses.transliteration:
evaṁ buddheḥ paraṁ buddhvā saṁstabhyātmānam ātmanā |
jahi śhatruṁ mahā-bāho kāma-rūpaṁ durāsadam || 43 ||

translations.english: Thus, knowing the Self to be superior to the material intellect, O mighty-armed Arjuna, steady the lower self (mind) by the higher Self (intellect's strength), and conquer this formidable enemy known as desire.
